           <div class="publication-abstract" data-reactid="123">
            <div class="nova-e-text nova-e-text--size-xl nova-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-e-text--spacing-xs" data-reactid="124">
             Abstract
            </div>
            <div class="nova-e-text nova-e-text--size-m nova-e-text--family-sans-serif nova-e-text--spacing-auto" data-reactid="125">
             Researchers in the field of bioinformatics often face a challenge of combining several ordered lists in a proper and efficient manner. Rank aggregation techniques offer a general and flexible framework that allows one to objectively perform the necessary aggregation. With the rapid growth of high-throughput genomic and proteomic studies, the potential utility of rank aggregation in the context of meta-analysis becomes even more apparent. One of the major strengths of rank-based aggregation is the ability to combine lists coming from different sources and platforms, for example different microarray chips, which may or may not be directly comparable otherwise. The RankAggreg package provides two methods for combining the ordered lists: the Cross-Entropy method and the Genetic Algorithm. Two examples of rank aggregation using the package are given in the manuscript: one in the context of clustering based on gene expression, and the other one in the context of meta-analysis of prostate cancer microarray experiments. The two examples described in the manuscript clearly show the utility of the RankAggreg package in the current bioinformatics context where ordered lists are routinely produced as a result of modern high-throughput technologies.
            </div>
           </div>

               <span class="_ _1"></span>ibution, and r

              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 ha ye ff3 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls4 wsf">
               Abstract
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hb yf ff3 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws10">
               Background: 
               <span class="ff5 ls1f ws11">Researchers in the field of bioinformatics often face a challenge of combinin<span class="_ _1"></span>g</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hc y10 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls6 ws12">
               several ordered lists in a proper and efficient ma
               <span class="ls7 ws13">nner. Rank aggregation techniques offer a general</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hc y11 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls7 ws14">
               and flexible framework that allows one to objectively perform the necessary aggregation. With the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hc y12 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls8 ws15">
               rapid growth of high-throughput genomic and pr
               <span class="ls9 ws16">oteomic studies, the potential utility of rank</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hc y13 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsa ws17">
               aggregation in the context of meta-analysis becomes even more apparent. One of the major
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hc y14 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsb ws18">
               strengths of rank-based aggregation is the ability to combine lists coming from different sources and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hc y15 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsc ws19">
               platforms, for example different microarray chips, which may or may not be directly comparable
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hc y16 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsd ws1a">
               otherwise.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hb y17 ff3 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws1b">
               Results: 
               <span class="ff5 ls20 ws1c">The <span class="ff6 ls7 ws1d">RankAggreg </span><span class="lsf ws1e">package provides two methods for combining the ordered lists: the</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hc y18 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls6 ws1f">
               Cross-Entropy method and the G
               <span class="lsa ws20">enetic Algorithm. Two examples of rank aggregation using the</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hc y19 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls10 ws21">
               package are given in the manuscript: one in the context of clustering based on gene expression, and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hc y1a ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls10 ws22">
               the other one in the context of meta-analysis of prostate cancer microarray experiments.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hb y1b ff3 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws23">
               Conclusion: 
               <span class="ff5 ls13 ws24">The two examples described in the manuscript clearly show the utility of the</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hc y1c ff6 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws25">
               RankAggreg 
               <span class="ff5 ls12 ws26">package in the current bioinformatics context where ordered lists are routinely</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2 hc y1d ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls13 ws27">
               produced as a result of modern high-throughput technologies.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 ha y1e ff3 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls14 ws28">
               Background
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y1f ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws29">
               Rank aggrega
               <span class="_ _0"></span>tion has a long histo
               <span class="_ _0"></span>ry with its roots tra
               <span class="_ _0"></span>cing
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y20 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls21 ws2a">
               back to th
               <span class="_ _1"></span>e voting t
               <span class="_ _1"></span>heory of t
               <span class="_ _1"></span>he 18
              </div>
              <div class="t m1 x3 he y21 ff8 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls1e">
               th
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4 hd y22 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws2b">
               century. The Bo
               <span class="_ _0"></span>rda
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y23 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws2c">
               count is perhaps th
               <span class="_ _0"></span>e most famous suc
               <span class="_ _0"></span>h method where
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y24 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws2d">
               elements in th
               <span class="_ _0"></span>e overall list are or
               <span class="_ _0"></span>dered accor
               <span class="_ _0"></span>ding to the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y25 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws2e">
               average rank c
               <span class="_ _0"></span>omputed from th
               <span class="_ _0"></span>e ranks in all indiv
               <span class="_ _0"></span>idual lists
               <span class="_ _0"></span>.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y26 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws2f">
               Other rank agg
               <span class="_ _0"></span>regation sch
               <span class="_ _0"></span>emes have been pr
               <span class="_ _0"></span>oposed over
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y27 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws30">
               the years and they dif
               <span class="_ _0"></span>fer greatly in b
               <span class="_ _0"></span>oth the underly
               <span class="_ _0"></span>ing
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y28 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws31">
               philosoph
               <span class="_ _0"></span>y, as well as mathe
               <span class="_ _0"></span>matical com
               <span class="_ _0"></span>plexity
               <span class="_ _0"></span>.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y29 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls15 ws32">
               Two radically different philo
               <span class="ls6 ws33">sophies on rank aggregation</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y2a ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws34">
               exist. The first one is based on the majoritarian principles
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y2b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws35">
               and attempts to accommodate the "majority" of indivi-
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y2c ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls16 ws36">
               dual preferences putting less or no weight on the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y2d ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 ws37">
               relatively infrequent ones. The final aggregate ranking
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2e ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls18 ws38">
               is usually based on the number of pairwise wins between
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2f ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws39">
               items within individual lists. If item "A" is ranked higher
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y30 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls22 ws3a">
               t
               <span class="_ _6"></span>h
               <span class="_ _6"></span>a
               <span class="_ _6"></span>ni
               <span class="_ _6"></span>t
               <span class="_ _6"></span>e
               <span class="_ _6"></span>m"
               <span class="_ _6"></span>B
               <span class="_ _6"></span>"m
               <span class="_ _6"></span>o
               <span class="_ _6"></span>r
               <span class="_ _6"></span>eo
               <span class="_ _6"></span>f
               <span class="_ _6"></span>t
               <span class="_ _6"></span>e
               <span class="_ _6"></span>nt
               <span class="_ _6"></span>h
               <span class="_ _6"></span>a
               <span class="_ _6"></span>nn
               <span class="_ _6"></span>o
               <span class="_ _6"></span>t
               <span class="_ _6"></span>,t
               <span class="_ _6"></span>h
               <span class="_ _6"></span>e
               <span class="_ _6"></span>ni
               <span class="_ _6"></span>t
               <span class="_ _6"></span>e
               <span class="_ _6"></span>m"
               <span class="_ _6"></span>A
               <span class="_ _6"></span>"s
               <span class="_ _6"></span>h
               <span class="_ _6"></span>o
               <span class="_ _6"></span>u
               <span class="_ _6"></span>l
               <span class="_ _6"></span>d
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y31 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 ws3b">
               also be ranked higher than item "B" in the overall list.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y32 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls19 ws3c">
               Any method that satisfies this condition, known as the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y33 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws3d">
               Condorcet criterion, is called the Condorcet method. The
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y34 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 ws3e">
               second philosophical approach to rank aggregation seeks
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y35 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls15 ws3f">
               the consensus among individual ordered lists and is
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y36 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls19 ws40">
               usually based on some form of rank averaging. The
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y37 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws41">
               Borda count is a good representative of this category. It is
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y38 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws42">
               possible that the two approaches will produce different
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y39 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws43">
               aggregated lists if applied to the same problem.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y3a ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws44">
               Conceptually, rank aggregation techniques range from
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y3b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws45">
               quite simple (based on rank average or on a number of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x6 hf y3c ff9 fs8 fc0 sc0 ls1a ws46">
               Page 1 of 10
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 h10 y3d ffa fs9 fc0 sc0 ls1b ws47">
               (page number not for citation purposes)
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x8 h11 y3e ffb fsa fc1 sc0 ls23 ws48">
               Bio
               <span class="fc2">Med<span class="ffc ls1e ws49"> <span class="_ _6"></span><span class="ffd fc0 ls23">Central</span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x6 h12 y3f ffe fsb fc3 sc0 ls24 ws49">
               Open Access
              </div>
              <a class="l" href="deref/http%3A%2F%2Fcreativecommons.org%2Flicenses%2Fby%2F2.0">
               <div class="d m2" style="border-style:none;position:absolute;left:657.673602px;bottom:837.826614px;width:139.352000px;height:7.994000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="deref/http%3A%2F%2Fwww.biomedcentral.com%2F">
               <div class="d m2" style="border-style:none;position:absolute;left:813.781901px;bottom:1192.837565px;width:66.599000px;height:29.400000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
              <a class="l" href="deref/http%3A%2F%2Fwww.biomedcentral.com%2Finfo%2Fabout%2Fcharter%2F">
               <div class="d m2" style="border-style:none;position:absolute;left:800.576346px;bottom:1112.542327px;width:84.278000px;height:17.919000px;background-color:rgba(255,255,255,0.000001);"></div></a>
             </div>
             <div class="pi" data-data="{&quot;ctm&quot;:[1.606515,0.000000,0.000000,1.606515,0.000000,0.000000]}"></div>
            </div> 
           </div> 
           <div class="pdf-viewer-page"> 
            <div id="pf2" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="2">
             <div class="pc pc2 w0 h0">
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y40 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws4a">
               pairwise wins) to fairly c
               <span class="ls15 ws4b">omplex which may employ</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y41 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws4c">
               advanced computational methodologies to find a solu-
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y42 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws4d">
               tion. Simpl
               <span class="_ _1"></span>e solution
               <span class="_ _1"></span>s are not nec
               <span class="_ _1"></span>essarily de
               <span class="_ _1"></span>sirable a
               <span class="_ _1"></span>s
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y43 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls6 ws4e">
               they usually rely on "ad hoc" principles and lack any
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y44 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws4f">
               formal justification. Mathematical rigor brings certain
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y45 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws50">
               satisfaction and "security" at the expense of increased
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y46 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws51">
               complexi
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ty and inten
               <span class="_ _1"></span>sive comp
               <span class="_ _1"></span>utation.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y47 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws52">
               Rank aggregation methods have a lot of potential in the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y48 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls26 ws53">
               field of bioinformatics. Ordered lists are routinely
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y49 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls18 ws54">
               produced by today's high-throughput techniques which
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y4a ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls55 ws55">
               n
               <span class="_ _7"></span>a
               <span class="_ _7"></span>t
               <span class="_ _7"></span>u
               <span class="_ _7"></span>r
               <span class="_ _7"></span>a
               <span class="_ _7"></span>l
               <span class="_ _7"></span>l
               <span class="_ _7"></span>yl
               <span class="_ _7"></span>e
               <span class="_ _7"></span>n
               <span class="_ _7"></span>dt
               <span class="_ _7"></span>h

               <span class="_ _7"></span>e

               <span class="_ _7"></span>e

               <span class="_ _7"></span>oam
               <span class="_ _7"></span>e
               <span class="_ _7"></span>t
               <span class="_ _7"></span>a
               <span class="_ _7"></span>-
               <span class="_ _7"></span>a
               <span class="_ _7"></span>n
               <span class="_ _7"></span>a
               <span class="_ _7"></span>l
               <span class="_ _7"></span>y
               <span class="_ _7"></span>s
               <span class="_ _7"></span>i
               <span class="_ _7"></span>s
               <span class="_ _0"></span>t
               <span class="_ _7"></span>h

               <span class="_ _7"></span>g
               <span class="_ _7"></span>h
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y4b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws56">
               rank aggregation. [1, 2] proposed to use rank aggregation
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y4c ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws57">
               methods to integrate the results of several microarray
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y4d ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws58">
               studies (ordered lists of genes), [3, 4] suggested aggrega-
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y4e ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls27 ws59">
               tion of miRNA targets predicted by three popular
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y4f ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws5a">
               software packages and [5] used rank aggregation to
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y50 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws5b">
               order clustering algorithms evaluated by several valida-
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y51 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws5c">
               tion measures. The list can easily be extended to other
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y52 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws5d">
               potential applications, in particular, in proteomics for
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y53 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls6 ws5e">
               the purpose of integrating biomarkers from different
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y54 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls15 ws5f">
               studies or in the context of clustering analysis where the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y55 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws60">
               unknown n
               <span class="_ _1"></span>umber of clu
               <span class="_ _1"></span>sters, in
               <span class="_ _1"></span>stead of th
               <span class="_ _1"></span>e "best"
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y56 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls29 ws61">
               algorithm, needs to be determined. In this paper, we
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y57 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2a ws62">
               present an R 
               <span class="ff8 ws63">RankAggreg </span>
               <span class="ls2b ws64">package available through</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y58 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2c ws65">
               CRAN http://cran.r-projec
               <span class="ls2d ws66">t.org/web/packages/RankAg-</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y59 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsa ws67">
               greg/ which provides two different algorithms for rank
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y5a ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsf ws68">
               aggregation: the Cross-Entropy Monte Carlo algorithm
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y5b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls7 ws69">
               (CE) [6, 7] and the Genetic algorithm (GA) [8]. Both
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y5c ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2e ws6a">
               methods are available through the main function
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y5d ff8 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsd ws1a">
               RankAggreg
               <span class="ff4 ls10 ws6b">. In addition, a brute force algorithm is also</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y5e ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws6c">
               provided through the 
               <span class="ff8 ws6d">BruteAggreg </span>
               <span class="ls1e ws6e">function wh<span class="_ _1"></span>ich simply</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y5f ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1f ws6f">
               tries all possible solutions and selects the one which is
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y60 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws70">
               optimal. What is meant by "optimal" and how to find
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y61 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws71">
               the "optimal" solution will be the discussion of the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y62 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2f ws43">
               Methods section.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 ha y63 ff3 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls30 ws72">
               Implementation
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 h13 y64 fff fsc fc0 sc0 ls31 ws73">
               Rank aggregation as an o
               <span class="ls56 ws74">ptimization problem</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y65 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsa ws75">
               To cast the rank aggregation in the framework of an
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y66 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls32 ws62">
               optimization problem, we f
               <span class="ls33 ws76">irst need to define the</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y67 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws77">
               objective function. In this context, we would like to
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y68 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls34 ws78">
               find a "super"-list which would be as "close" as possible
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y69 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsf ws79">
               to all individual ordered lists simultaneously. This is a
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y6a ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsf ws7a">
               natural requirement and the objective function, at least
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y6b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls15 ws7b">
               in its most abstract form, is very simple and intuitive
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x9 h14 y6c ff10 fsd fc4 sc0 ls1e ws7c">
               ?
               <span class="ff11 ls57 ws7d">()<span class="_ _8"> </span>(, )<span class="_ _7"></span>,</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m3 xa h15 y6c ff12 fse fc4 sc0 ls58">
               dd
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xb h14 y6c ff10 fsd fc4 sc0 ls1e">
               =
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xc h16 y6d ff10 fsf fc4 sc0 ls1e">
               =
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xd h17 y6e ff10 fs10 fc4 sc0 ls35">
               ?
               <span class="ff13 fsd ls36 ws7e v1">wd L</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xe h18 y6f ff13 fsf fc4 sc0 ls59">
               ii
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xf h18 y6d ff13 fsf fc4 sc0 ls1e">
               i
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xc h18 y70 ff13 fsf fc4 sc0 ls1e">
               m
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x10 h19 y6d ff11 fsf fc4 sc0 ls1e">
               1
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y71 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws7f">
               where 
               <span class="ff14 ls37">?</span>
               <span class="ls3c ws80">is a proposed ordered list of length <span class="ff8 ls37">k</span><span class="ls5a ws81">=|<span class="_ _6"></span><span class="ff8 ls1e">L</span></span></span>
              </div>

              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x12 hd y71 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws82">
               |, 
               <span class="ff8 ls1e">w</span>

               i
              </div>

               is
              </div>

               the importance weight associated with list 
               <span class="ff8 ls1e">L</span>

               ,
               <span class="ff8 ls39">d</span>
               <span class="ls3a ws84">is a</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y76 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsc ws85">
               distance function which will be discussed in details
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y77 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws86">
               below, and 
               <span class="ff8 ls1e">L</span>
              </div>

               i
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x18 hd y79 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls3b ws87">
               is the 
               <span class="ff8 ls1e">i</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m1 x19 he y7a ff8 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls5b">
               th
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 xb hd y79 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsf ws7b">
               ordered list [3, 5].
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y7b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls34 ws88">
               The idea is to find 
               <span class="ff14 ls3c">?</span>
               <span class="ls28 ws89">* which would minimize the total</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y7c ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws8a">
               distance between 
               <span class="ff14 ls3c">?</span>
               <span class="ls5c ws8b">*a<span class="_ _9"></span>n<span class="_ _9"></span>d<span class="ff8 ls1e">L</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m1 x7 he y7d ff8 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls1e">
               i
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x7 hd y7e ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls8">
               's
              </div>
              <div class="t m3 x1a h15 y7f ff12 fse fc4 sc0 ls5d">

              </div>

               *a

               <span class="_ _d"></span>.

              <div class="t m0 x1d h17 y81 ff10 fs10 fc4 sc0 ls3d">

              <div class="t m0 x1e h18 y82 ff13 fsf fc4 sc0 ls59">

              <div class="t m0 x1f h18 y83 ff13 fsf fc4 sc0 ls1e">

              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y85 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls6 ws8d">
               Selecting the appropriate distance function 
               <span class="ff8 ls3e">d</span>
               <span class="ls3f ws8e">to measure</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y86 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws8f">
               the "distan
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ce" betw
               <span class="_ _1"></span>een ordere
               <span class="_ _1"></span>d lists is ve
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ry import
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ant.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y87 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsd ws90">
               Though many choices for a distance function can be
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y88 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 ws91">
               found in the literature, we concentrate on the two most
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y89 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws92">
               popular ones: Spearman footrule distance and Kendall's
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y8a ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws93">
               tau distance. The two distances usually produce slightly
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y8b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws94">
               different aggregated lists which is mainly due to the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y8c ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls12 ws95">
               differences in the two philosophical paradigms discussed
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y8d ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls40 ws96">
               in the Background section.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h13 y8e fff fsc fc0 sc0 ls41 ws97">
               Spearman footrule distance
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y8f ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls42 ws98">
               Before defining the two distance measures, let us
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y90 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls19 ws99">
               introduce some necessary notations. Let 
               <span class="ff8 ls1e">M</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m1 x21 he y91 ff8 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls1e">
               i
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x6 hd y92 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5f ws9a">
               (1),..., 
               <span class="ff8 ls1e">M</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m1 x22 he y91 ff8 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls1e">
               i
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x23 hd y92 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls43">
               (
               <span class="ff8 ls3c">k</span>
               <span class="ls1e">)</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y93 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws9b">
               be the scores associated with the ordered list 
               <span class="ff8 ls1e">L</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m1 x24 he y94 ff8 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls1e">
               i
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x25 hd y95 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls60 ws9c">
               ,w
               <span class="_ _c"></span>h
               <span class="_ _c"></span>e
               <span class="_ _c"></span>r
               <span class="_ _9"></span>e
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1a y96 ff8 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e">
               M
              </div>
              <div class="t m1 x26 he y97 ff8 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls1e">
               i
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x27 hd y98 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws9d">
               (1) is the best (
               <span class="_ _1"></span>can be the lar
               <span class="_ _1"></span>gest or the sm
               <span class="_ _1"></span>allest
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y99 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws9e">
               depending on the context) score, 
               <span class="ff8 ls1e">M</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m1 x28 he y9a ff8 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls1e">
               i
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x29 hd y9b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls61 ws9f">
               (2) is the second
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h1b y9c ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 wsa0">
               best, and so on. Let
               <span class="_ _f"> </span>
               <span class="ff13 fsd fc4 ls44 v2">r<span class="fsf ls45 v1">L<span class="fs11 ls46 v2">i</span></span></span>
               <span class="ls43 v0">(<span class="ff8 ls18">A</span><span class="ls62 wsa1">) be the rank of <span class="ff8 ls47">A</span><span class="ls18 wsa2">in the list <span class="ff8 ls1e">L</span></span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m1 x2a he y9d ff8 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls1e">
               i
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y9e ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 wsa3">
               (1 means "best") if 
               <span class="ff8 ls48">A</span>
               <span class="ls63 wsa4">is within the top <span class="ff8 ls3c">k</span><span class="ls18 wsa5">, and be equal to</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y9f ff8 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls49">
               k
               <span class="ff4 ls64 wsa6">+1<span class="_ _10"></span>,o<span class="_ _10"></span>t<span class="_ _10"></span>h<span class="_ _10"></span>e<span class="_ _10"></span>r<span class="_ _10"></span>w<span class="_ _10"></span>i<span class="_ _10"></span>s<span class="_ _10"></span>e<span class="_ _10"></span>;<span class="ff8 ls1e">r</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m1 x2b h1c ya0 ff14 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls1e">
               ?
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2c hd ya1 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls4a">
               (
               <span class="ff8 ls4b">A<span class="ff4 wsa7">) is defined likewise. The</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd ya2 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 wsa8">
               Spearman's footrule distance between 
               <span class="ff8 ls1e">L</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m1 x2d he ya3 ff8 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls1e">
               i
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2e hd ya4 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls6 wsa9">
               and any ordered
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd ya5 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls65 wsaa">
               list 
               <span class="ff14 ls4c">?</span>
               <span class="lsf wsab">can be defined as</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2f h1d ya6 ff13 fsd fc4 sc0 ls66 wsac">
               SL r
               <span class="_ _c"></span>t
               <span class="_ _11"> </span>r
               <span class="_ _0"></span>t
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x30 h18 ya7 ff13 fsf fc4 sc0 ls1e">
               i
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x28 h18 ya8 ff13 fsf fc4 sc0 ls1e">
               L
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x2b h18 ya9 ff13 fsf fc4 sc0 ls67">
               tL
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x29 h1e yaa ff13 fs11 fc4 sc0 ls1e">
               i
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x31 h1e yab ff13 fs11 fc4 sc0 ls1e">
               i
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x32 h1f ya6 ff11 fsd fc4 sc0 ls68 wsad">
               ( ,
               <span class="_ _12"> </span>)
               <span class="_ _13"> </span>|
               <span class="_ _14"> </span>()
               <span class="_ _15"> </span>()
               <span class="_ _6"></span>|
               <span class="_ _16"></span>.
              </div>
              <div class="t m3 x1a h20 ya6 ff12 fse fc4 sc0 ls4d">
               d
               <span class="fs12 ls1e v1">d</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m3 x7 h21 yac ff12 fs12 fc4 sc0 ls1e">
               d
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x33 h14 ya6 ff10 fsd fc4 sc0 ls69">
               =?
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x34 h16 yad ff10 fsf fc4 sc0 ls1e">
               ?
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x35 h17 yae ff10 fs10 fc4 sc0 ls1e">
               ?
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x36 h22 yad ff15 fsf fc4 sc0 ls1e">
               ?
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd yaf ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls19 wsae">
               It is nothing more than the summation of the absolute
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd yb0 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsb wsaf">
               differences between the ranks of all unique elements
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd yb1 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse wsb0">
               from both ordered lists combined. It is rather a very
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd yb2 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls15 wsb1">
               intuitive metric for comparing two ordered lists of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd yb3 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e wsb2">
               arbitrar
               <span class="_ _1"></span>y length. T
               <span class="_ _1"></span>he smaller
               <span class="_ _12"> </span>the value of the me
               <span class="_ _1"></span>tric,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd yb4 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2b wsb3">
               the more similar the lists. For Spearman's footrule
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd yb5 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 wsb4">
               distance, the maximum value when comparing two
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd yb6 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 wsb5">
               top-
               <span class="ff8 ls4e">k</span>
               <span class="ls4f wsb6">lists is <span class="ff8 ls50">k</span><span class="ls43">(<span class="ff8 ls4e">k</span><span class="ls8 wsb7">+ 1). It is attained when the two lists</span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd yb7 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 wsb8">
               have no elements in common.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd yb8 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse wsb9">
               The appeal of the Spearman footrule distance comes
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd yb9 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls3c wsba">
               from its simplicity and it is adequate in many situations
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd yba ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls40 wsbb">
               when the only information available about the indivi-
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd ybb ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 ws79">
               dual lists is the rank order of their elements. In a case
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd ybc ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 wsbc">
               when additional information which was used to rank the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd ybd ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 wsbd">
               lists in the first place is available, it would be beneficial
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd ybe ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e wsbe">
               and pruden
               <span class="_ _1"></span>t to incorpo
               <span class="_ _1"></span>rate this i
               <span class="_ _1"></span>nformati
               <span class="_ _1"></span>on into our
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd ybf ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls9 wsbf">
               aggregation scheme [5].
              </div>

              <div class="t m1 x47 h36 y104 ff4 fs7 fc0 sc0 ls1e">
               2
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x4a hd y105 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 wsf0">
               and this happens when the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y106 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 wsf1">

              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y107 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls3b wsf2">
               Intuitively, Kendall's tau can be thought about in the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y108 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsf wsf3">
               following way. If the two elements 
               <span class="ff8 ls7c">t</span>
               <span class="ls3c wsf4">and <span class="ff8 ls7d">u</span></span>
               <span class="wsf5">have the same</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y109 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsf wsf6">
               ordering in both lists, then no penalty is incurred (a good
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y10a ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 wsf7">
               scenario). If the element 
               <span class="ff8 ls7e">t</span>
               <span class="ls40 wsf8">precedes <span class="ff8 ls7f">u</span><span class="ls1e wsf9">in the first li<span class="_ _1"></span>st and <span class="ff8">u</span></span></span>
              </div>

               <span class="ff8 ls80">t</span>
               <span class="ls7 wsfb">in the second list, then a penalty of 1 is imposed</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y10c ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 wsfc">

               <span class="ff8 ls7e">t</span>
               <span class="ls81 wsfd">and <span class="ff8 ls7f">u</span><span class="ls1e wsfe">do not app<span class="_ _1"></span>ear</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y10d ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls81 wsff">

              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y10e ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 ws101">

              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y46 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws123">

              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y125 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls40 ws124">

              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y47 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws125">

               <span class="_ _1"></span>e interva
               <span class="_ _1"></span>l. We settle

              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y49 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5c ws8b">

               <span class="_ _9"></span>n

              <div class="t m0 x59 h37 y126 ff13 fsd fc4 sc0 ls8f">
               M
               <span class="ls1e ws126 v6">M</span>
               <span class="ls90 v1">i</span>
               <span class="ls1e ws126 v6">M<span class="v2">i</span></span>

              <div class="t m0 x5a h1d y127 ff13 fsd fc4 sc0 ls1e ws126">
               M

               <span class="_ _1d"> </span>min( )
               <span class="_ _11"> </span>
               <span class="lsbf ws129 v7">,<span class="_ _2f"> </span>,..., .<span class="_ _34"></span><span class="ff10 ls93">=<span class="ls1e v6">?</span></span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5c h3a y12a ff10 fsd fc4 sc0 ls94">

               <span class="ls95 v7">=<span class="ff11 ls1e">1</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y12b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws107">
               We would like t
               <span class="_ _1"></span>o make one las
               <span class="_ _1"></span>t comment on th
               <span class="_ _1"></span>e reasons
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y12c ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls29 ws12a">
               behind introducing weighted distance measures here.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y12d ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws12b">
               Quite obviously they are motivated by the desire for a
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y12e ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws12c">
               more efficient use of the data, in this case, the numerical
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y12f ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls40 ws22">
               scores which underlie the rankings. But that is not their
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y130 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws12d">
               sole purp
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ose. When u
               <span class="_ _1"></span>sing the or
               <span class="_ _1"></span>iginal Sp
               <span class="_ _1"></span>earman an
               <span class="_ _1"></span>d
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y131 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsc0 ws12e">
               Kendall distances we noticed that in many situations no
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y132 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls15 ws12f">
               clear winner exists as two or more ordered lists have the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y133 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws130">
               same objective function score due to the discrete nature
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y134 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws131">
               of ranks. This brought computational instability into the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y135 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 ws132">
               iterative aggregation process. The algorithm would never
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y136 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls40 ws133">
               converge but would simply oscillate between the two
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y137 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls3b ws134">
               "best" lists, understandably not knowing which one to
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y138 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2f ws135">
               pick. When continuous weights are used to adjust the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y139 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws136">
               discrete ranks, the possibility of such ties is almost
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y13a ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsa ws137">
               eliminated and the algorithm is much more computa-
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y13b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls6 ws138">
               tionally stable. In addition, we obtain a clear winner in
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y13c ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls40 ws139">
               an objective and rigorous way.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 h13 y13d fff fsc fc0 sc0 lsc1 ws13a">
               Cross-Entropy Monte Carlo algorithm
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y13e ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws13b">
               The details of the CE algorithm are given in [5]. [3]
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y13f ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 ws13c">
               explore the CE algorithm for rank aggregation in the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y140 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 ws13d">
               context of microRNA analysis 
               <span class="ls2f ws13e">and a very useful tutorial</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y141 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2f ws13f">
               on the CE algorithm with several examples is presented
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y142 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsc2 ws140">
               in [7]. Here, we only briefly describe the main st
               <span class="_ _1"></span>eps. The
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y143 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws141">
               CE is a stochastic search algorithm in the space of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y144 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls7 ws142">
               matrices with 0
               <span class="ff18 ls61">–</span>1 valued entries with columns summing
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y145 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws143">
               to one and rows summing to at most one since any
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y146 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 ws144">
               ordered list can be uniquely mapped to such a matrix.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y147 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls61 wscf">
               1. 
               <span class="ff19 ls96 ws145">Initialization: </span>
               <span class="lse ws146">Start with the uniform multinomial cell</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y148 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws147">
               probabilities.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y149 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls61 ws148">
               2. 
               <span class="ff19 lsc ws149">Sampling: </span>
               <span class="ls29 ws14a">At each stage, generate a random sample of</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y14a ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls29 ws14b">
               such matrices via restricte
               <span class="ls18 ws62">d (truncated) multinomial</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y14b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls18 ws14c">
               sampling with the current cell probabilities.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y14c ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls61 ws14d">
               3. 
               <span class="ff19 ls12 ws14e">Updating: </span>
               <span class="lsc2 ws14f">Based on the current sample and the value</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y14d ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsc3 ws150">
               of the objective function at 
               <span class="ls18 ws151">the corresponding ordered</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y14e ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls18 ws152">
               list update the multinomial cell probabilities such that
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hf yc2 ffa fs8 fc0 sc0 ls53 wsc4">
               BMC Bioinformatics 
               <span class="ff9 ls1a wsc5">2009, <span class="ff16 ls1e wsc6">10</span><span class="ls54 wsc7">:62 http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2105/10<span class="_ _16"></span>/<span class="_ _1"></span>62</span></span>
              </div>

             </div>
