              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y273 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws2ff">
               Based on the value of the objective function, we prefer
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y274 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws12">
               the list identified by the CE algorithm in this case. From
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y275 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws300">
               that list,
               <span class="_ _12"> </span>9 genes w
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ere previ
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ously link
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ed to prost
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ate
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y276 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsf ws301">
               cancer development in the literature: HPN, AMACR,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y277 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsc ws302">
               GDF15, FASN, SLC25A6, KRT18, ALCAM, CCT2, and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y278 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws303">
               MTHFD2. Note that 6 of them are among the top-10
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y279 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsa ws304">
               genes in the obtained list. [11] find strong evidence for
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y27a ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws114">
               HPN's association with prostate cancer susceptibility and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y27b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws305">
               tumor aggressiveness, AMACR was shown to be over-
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y27c ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws26e">
               expressed in prostate cancer by [12], and [13] propose to
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y27d ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws306">
               use FASN, which is also overexpressed, as a therapeutic
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y27e ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws307">
               target for prostate cancer. If we, for example, ignored the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y27f ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws308">
               overall list for a moment and concentrated on the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y280 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls34 ws309">
               individual lists, we would miss a clearly important gene
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y281 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2f ws30a">
               FASN 2 out of 5 times as it does not appear in Luo and
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y282 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls6 ws30b">
               True top-25 lists. The overall list, which borrows the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y283 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls15 ws30c">
               information across the studies, places FASN in the fourth
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y284 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls6 ws2ae">
               place making it impossible to overlook.
              </div>

              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y286 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws30e">
               the same five gene lists with the results presented in
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y287 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls34 wsfc">
               Table 2 in their original manuscript. The obtained list for
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y288 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws30f">
               the unweighted Spearman column is very similar to the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y289 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsf ws13">
               one obtained using the 
               <span class="ff8 ls9 ws310">RankAggreg( ) </span>
               <span class="ls13 ws311">function. On their</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y28a ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws312">
               supplementary website, the authors made available an R
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y28b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws313">
               function that performs rank aggregation using the CE
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y28c ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsba ws314">
               algorithm; the underlying code is written in C. At this
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y28d ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2f ws315">
               time, it is somewhat faster than the 
               <span class="ff8 ls6 ws316">RankAggreg( )</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y28e ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws317">
               function but it lacks the user-friendliness and exibility
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y28f ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls40 ws318">
               that our package offers. In addition, it provides no
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y290 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls6 ws319">
               alternatives to the CE algorithm and does not make use
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y291 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2f ws31a">
               of the weighted distance functions that we proposed.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y292 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11e ws31b">
               To give a reader some perspective on whether the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y293 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsf ws31c">
               computational overhead is well justified in this case,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y294 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsc4 ws2d7">
               we aggregated the five lists using the Borda count
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y295 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws31d">
               method desc
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ribed in t
               <span class="_ _1"></span>he Backgr
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ound sect
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ion. Accor
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ding
              </div>

            <div id="pf9" class="pf w0 h0" data-page-no="9">
             <div class="pc pc9 w0 h0">
              <div class="bi x1 y216 w4 h42 lazyload" data-bg="profile/Somnath_Datta2/publication/24026315/viewer/AS:209103138889735@1426865481825/background/9.png" style="background-size: contain;"></div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y40 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2f ws325">
               weights. The order of other genes, however, is different.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y41 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e wsb2">
               The lists sh
               <span class="_ _1"></span>are 18 common g
               <span class="_ _1"></span>enes among t
               <span class="_ _1"></span>he two of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y42 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsa ws326">
               them. Using the Spearman distance, we calculated the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y43 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls18 ws327">
               objective function score for the list obtained from the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y44 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls12d ws328">
               B
               <span class="_ _c"></span>o
               <span class="_ _c"></span>r
               <span class="_ _c"></span>d
               <span class="_ _9"></span>ac
               <span class="_ _c"></span>o
               <span class="_ _c"></span>u
               <span class="_ _c"></span>n
               <span class="_ _c"></span>ta
               <span class="_ _9"></span>n
               <span class="_ _c"></span>di
               <span class="_ _c"></span>tt
               <span class="_ _c"></span>u
               <span class="_ _9"></span>r
               <span class="_ _c"></span>n
               <span class="_ _c"></span>e
               <span class="_ _c"></span>do
               <span class="_ _c"></span>u
               <span class="_ _9"></span>tt
               <span class="_ _c"></span>ob
               <span class="_ _c"></span>e3
               <span class="_ _c"></span>3
               <span class="_ _c"></span>3
               <span class="_ _9"></span>.
               <span class="_ _c"></span>6
               <span class="_ _c"></span>,w

               <span class="_ _c"></span>sa
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y45 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls127 ws316">
               little worse than 319.6 that we get using the CE
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y46 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws329">
               algorithm. Thus, the extra cost in computing may be
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y125 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws32a">
               well justified as we obtained a better list with a smaller
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y47 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsd">
               score.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y49 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws32b">
               Figure 3: Plots created by the 
               <span class="ff8 ls12e ws32c">plot( ) </span>
               <span class="lse ws32d">function for the GA</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y4a ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws32e">
               rank aggregation of the gene lists. We can see that
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y4b ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls29 ws32f">
               algorithm stabilized after roughly 500 iterations. The
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y4c ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2f ws330">
               distribution of the population in the final generation is
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y4d ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsf ws331">
               concentrated just to the right of the optimal solution.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y4e ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws332">
               The bottom plot clearly shows why the solution makes
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y4f ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsc4 ws3c">
               sense. Genes ranked high in the final list usually come
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hd y50 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws333">
               from several individual lists as indicated by the presence
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y1a9 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsd5 ws334">
               of multiple intersecting lines. The genes at the end of the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y1aa ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls3b ws335">
               final list are the ones included in a single list but
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y29d ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2f ws336">
               somewhere close to the top. The rank of 26 is artificial in
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y1ab ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws26e">
               our procedure and it simply indicates that that particular
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y1ac ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls3b ws337">
               gene is not present in the individual list.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 ha y29e ff3 fs5 fc0 sc0 ls128 ws338">
               Conclusion
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y29f ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls81 ws339">
               The 
               <span class="ff8 ls12f ws33a">RankAggreg </span>
               <span class="ls28 ws33b">package provides an easy and convenient</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2a0 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws33c">
               interface to handle complex rank aggregation problems.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2a1 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls15 ws33d">
               It performs rank aggregation using two different algo-
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2a2 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls29 ws33e">
               rithms with a choice of two different distances. The brute
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2a3 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws33f">
               force approach is also available for small-scale problems.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2a4 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws340">
               A simple plot function helps to visualize the rank
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2a5 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws341">
               aggregation problem and the obtained solution.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2a6 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls6 ws342">
               The effectiveness of the CE and the GA algorithms in
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2a7 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls81 ws343">
               discovering optimal lists is certainly limited by the size
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2a8 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls17 ws344">
               of the aggregation problem. As both algorithms need to
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2a9 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws345">
               effectiv
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ely search t
               <span class="_ _1"></span>he soluti
               <span class="_ _1"></span>on space, wh
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ich even in
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2aa ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2f ws346">
               moderate aggregation problem
               <span class="ls130 ws347">s (for example, dis<span class="_ _16"></span>cover-</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2ab ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls29 ws348">
               ing a top-25 list) is extremely large, there exists a
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2ac ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws349">
               practical limitation as to what problems can be handled.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2ad ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws193">
               The exampl
               <span class="_ _1"></span>es present
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ed in this ar
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ticle are r
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ather of a
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2ae ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls18 ws34a">
               moderate size but larger problems can definitely be
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2af ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws171">
               tackled. Top-100 lists with a significant amount of
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2b0 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls129 ws14b">
               overlap in terms of their content can certainly be
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2b1 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws2ee">
               aggregated using either one of the proposed algorithms.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2b2 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls11 ws34b">
               How well they will perform in aggregation of much
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2b3 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls16 ws34c">
               larger problems remains to be investigated. In the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2b4 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsb ws1ca">
               bioinformatics context, however, researchers are often
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2b5 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls3a ws34d">
               interested in a relatively small number (20
               <span class="ff18 ls6a">–</span>
               <span class="ls61 ws34e">50) of</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2b6 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws34f">
               significant discoveries and their aggregation is within
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2b7 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsba ws350">
               the limits of the proposed methodology.
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2b8 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsa ws351">
               We would like to stress that using either the CE or the GA
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2b9 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls25 ws352">
               algorithms for large problems does not "guarantee" an
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2ba ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2f ws353">
               optimal solution. Performance of both of these algo-
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2bb ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls29 ws354">
               rithms is quite sensitive to the tuning parameters, in
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2bc ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e wsf9">
               particul
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ar the sampl
               <span class="_ _1"></span>e size 
               <span class="ff8 ls12a">N</span>
               <span class="ls4f ws355">for the CE algorithm and the</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2bd ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws356">
               cross-ov
               <span class="_ _1"></span>er (CP) and m
               <span class="_ _1"></span>utation (M
               <span class="_ _1"></span>P) probab
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ilities for
               <span class="_ _2"> </span>the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2be ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls131 ws357">
               GA algorithm. The user i
               <span class="ls12b ws358">s encouraged to run the</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2bf ff8 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsd ws359">
               RankAggreg( ) 
               <span class="ff4 ls17 ws35a">function several times. If different optimal</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2c0 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws1f0">
               lists are pr
               <span class="_ _1"></span>oduced, in
               <span class="_ _1"></span>creasing sa
               <span class="_ _1"></span>mple size i
               <span class="_ _1"></span>s probably
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2c1 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws35b">
               necessary. Tuning additional parameters as discussed
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2c2 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 lse ws1ff">
               above may also prevent local minima traps. That said,
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2c3 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls7 ws35c">
               however, we are quite impressed by the ability of both
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2c4 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls5 ws35d">
               algorithms, the CE in particular, in discovering the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x5 hd y2c5 ff4 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls18 ws26d">
               optimal ordering of the elements in the combined list.
              </div>

              <div class="t m0 x69 h3f y2d5 ff1b fs1e fc5 sc0 ls1e ws279">

               <span class="_ _42"> </span>Mean
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hb y2d6 ff3 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls101 ws2b3">
               Figure 3
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hb y2d7 ff3 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws7b">
               Rank aggregation of gene lists using the GA
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hb y2d8 ff3 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls28 ws366">
               algorithm
               <span class="ff5 ls29 ws367">. Plots created by the <span class="ff6 ls96 wsbd">plot( ) </span><span class="ls12 ws368">function for the GA</span></span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hc y2d9 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsb ws369">
               rank aggregation of the gene lists. We can see that algorithm
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hc y2da ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls29 ws36a">
               stabilized after roughly 500 iterations. The distribution of the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hc y2db ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls10 ws36b">
               population in the final generation is concentrated just to the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hc y2dc ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls13 ws36c">
               right of the optimal solution. The bottom plot clearly shows
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hc y2dd ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsd ws35a">
               why the solution makes sense. Genes ranked high in the final
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hc y2de ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 lsf ws96">
               list usually come from several individual lists as indicated by
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hc y2df ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls2f ws36d">
               the presence of multiple lines intersecting. The genes at the
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hc y2e0 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls96 ws36e">
               end of the final list are the ones included in a single list but
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hc y2e1 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls9 ws36f">
               somewhere close to the top. The rank of 26 is artificial in our
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hc y2e2 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls96 ws370">
               procedure and it simply indicates that that particular gene is
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x1 hc y2e3 ff5 fs6 fc0 sc0 ls7 wsc3">
               not present in the individual list.
              </div>

               <span class="_ _4"> </span>P
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ihur V, Datta S a
               <span class="_ _1"></span>nd Datta S: 
               <span class="ff3 ws39f">Weig<span class="_ _1"></span>hted rank aggr<span class="_ _1"></span>egation of</span>
              </div>
              <div class="t m0 x3d h8 y2ff ff3 fs4 fc0 sc0 ls1e ws3a0">
               cluster valid
               <span class="_ _1"></span>ation measur
               <span class="_ _1"></span>es: a Monte Ca
               <span class="_ _1"></span>rlo cross-en
               <span class="_ _1"></span>tropy
              </div>

                    <li class="citation-context-item" data-reactid="24"><span class="citation-context-text" data-reactid="25">
                      <!-- react-text: 26 -->Rank aggregation approaches ( Dwork, Kumar, Naor, &amp; Sivakumar, 2001 ) have been proposed to identify the optimal ranked list of items over multiple lists. In the current study, we employ the RankAggreg library ( 
                      <!-- /react-text --><span class="citation-context-reference" data-reactid="27">Pihur &amp; Datta, 2009 </span>
                      <!-- react-text: 28 -->) to identify the optimal ranked lists for the four requirements. Specifically, Cross-Entropy Monte-Carlo algorithm (CE) with two distance measures Spearman footrule distance and Kendall's tau distance is used for the rank aggregation. 
                      <!-- /react-text --></span>
                     <div class="citation-enriched-context-actions clearfix" data-reactid="29"></div></li>
                   </ul>
                   <div style="margin-top:-2px;" data-reactid="30">
                    <h5 class="pub-type-and-title" data-reactid="31"><a class="js-publication-title-link ga-publication-item" itemprop="mainEntityOfPage" href="publication/314134911_Using_author-specified_keywords_in_building_an_initial_reading_list_of_research_papers_in_scientific_paper_retrieval_and_recommender_systems" data-reactid="32"><span class="publication-title js-publication-title" itemprop="headline" data-reactid="33">Using author-specified keywords in building an initial reading list of research papers in scientific paper retrieval and recommender systems</span></a></h5>
                   </div>
                   <div class="abstract" data-reactid="34">
                    <span class="shorten" data-reactid="35"><a href="#" data-reactid="36">
                      <!-- react-text: 37 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 38 -->[Show abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a></span>
                    <span class="full" data-reactid="39"><a href="#" data-reactid="40">
                      <!-- react-text: 41 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 42 -->[Hide abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a>
                     <!-- react-text: 43 -->
                     <!-- /react-text --><span data-reactid="44"><strong data-reactid="45">ABSTRACT:</strong>
                      <!-- react-text: 46 --> 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 47 -->An initial reading list is prepared by researchers at the start of literature review for getting an overview of the research performed in a particular area. Prior studies have taken the approach of merely recommending seminal or popular papers to aid researchers in such a task. In this paper, we present an alternative technique called the AKR (Author-specified Keywords based Retrieval) technique for providing popular, recent, survey and a diverse set of papers as a part of the initial reading list. The AKR technique is based on a novel coverage value that has its calculation centered on author-specified keywords. We performed an offline evaluation experiment with four variants of the AKR technique along with three state-of-the-art approaches involving collaborative filtering and graph ranking algorithms. Findings show that the Hyperlink-Induced Topic Search (HITS) enhanced variant of the AKR technique performs better than other techniques, satisfying most requirements for a reading list. A user evaluation study was conducted with 132 researchers to gauge user interest on the proposed technique using 14 evaluation measures. Results show that (i) students group are more satisfied with the recommended papers than staff group, (ii) popularity measure is strongly correlated with the output quality measures and (iii) the measures familiarity, usefulness and ‘agreeability on a good list’ were found to be strong predictors for user satisfaction. The AKR technique provides scope for extension in future information retrieval (IR) and content-based recommender systems (RS) studies.
                      <!-- /react-text --></span></span>
                   </div>

                   <ul class="citation-contexts" data-reactid="73">
                    <li class="citation-context-item" data-reactid="74"><span class="citation-context-text" data-reactid="75">
                      <!-- react-text: 76 -->The intuition behind using rank aggregation is that items that are highly ranked in many lists, are also highly ranked in the output list. In particular, we use a weighted rank-aggregation technique proposed by Pihur et al.
                      <!-- /react-text --><span class="citation-context-reference" data-reactid="77">[16]</span>
                      <!-- react-text: 78 -->: the goal is to minimize an objective function 
                      <!-- /react-text --></span>
                     <div class="citation-enriched-context-actions clearfix" data-reactid="79"></div></li>

                   <div style="margin-top:-2px;" data-reactid="80">
                    <h5 class="pub-type-and-title" data-reactid="81"><a class="js-publication-title-link ga-publication-item" itemprop="mainEntityOfPage" href="publication/315749614_Exposing_Twitter_Users_to_Contrarian_News" data-reactid="82"><span class="publication-title js-publication-title" itemprop="headline" data-reactid="83">Exposing Twitter Users to Contrarian News</span></a></h5>
                   </div>
                   <div class="abstract" data-reactid="84">
                    <span class="shorten" data-reactid="85"><a href="#" data-reactid="86">
                      <!-- react-text: 87 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 88 -->[Show abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a></span>
                    <span class="full" data-reactid="89"><a href="#" data-reactid="90">
                      <!-- react-text: 91 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 92 -->[Hide abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a>
                     <!-- react-text: 93 -->
                     <!-- /react-text --><span data-reactid="94"><strong data-reactid="95">ABSTRACT:</strong>
                      <!-- react-text: 96 --> 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 97 -->Polarized topics often spark discussion and debate on social media. Recent studies have shown that polarized debates have a specific clustered structure in the endorsement net- work, which indicates that users direct their endorsements mostly to ideas they already agree with. Understanding these polarized discussions and exposing social media users to content that broadens their views is of paramount importance. The contribution of this demonstration is two-fold. (i) A tool to visualize retweet networks about controversial issues on Twitter. By using our visualization, users can understand how polarized discussions are shaped on Twitter, and explore the positions of the various actors. (ii) A solution to reduce polarization of such discussions. We do so by exposing users to information which presents a contrarian point of view. Users can visually inspect our recommendations and understand why and how these would play out in terms of the retweet network. Our demo (https://users.ics.aalto.fi/kiran/reducingControversy/ homepage) provides one of the first steps in developing automated tools that help users explore, and possibly escape, their echo chambers. The ideas in the demo can also help content providers design tools to broaden their reach to people with different political and ideological backgrounds.
                      <!-- /react-text --></span></span>
                   </div>

                    <li class="citation-context-item" data-reactid="132"><span class="citation-context-text" data-reactid="133">
                      <!-- react-text: 134 -->We should not be forced to assume that some information exists, if in fact we have none. We have considered using the R package RankAggreg (
                      <!-- /react-text --><span class="citation-context-reference" data-reactid="135">Pihur et al. (2014)</span>
                      <!-- react-text: 136 -->), but unfortunately we would have to attribute a concrete rank (e.g. k + 1) to all missing elements. 
                      <!-- /react-text --></span>
                     <div class="citation-enriched-context-actions clearfix" data-reactid="137"></div></li>
                   </ul>
                   <div style="margin-top:-2px;" data-reactid="138">
                    <h5 class="pub-type-and-title" data-reactid="139"><a class="js-publication-title-link ga-publication-item" itemprop="mainEntityOfPage" href="publication/306474551_Effect_of_Incomplete_Meta-dataset_on_Average_Ranking_Method" data-reactid="140"><span class="publication-title js-publication-title" itemprop="headline" data-reactid="141">Effect of Incomplete Meta-dataset on Average Ranking Method</span></a></h5>
                   </div>
                   <div class="abstract" data-reactid="142">
                    <span class="shorten" data-reactid="143"><a href="#" data-reactid="144">
                      <!-- react-text: 145 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 146 -->[Show abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a></span>
                    <span class="full" data-reactid="147"><a href="#" data-reactid="148">
                      <!-- react-text: 149 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 150 -->[Hide abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a>
                     <!-- react-text: 151 -->
                     <!-- /react-text --><span data-reactid="152"><strong data-reactid="153">ABSTRACT:</strong>
                      <!-- react-text: 154 --> 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 155 -->One of the simplest metalearning methods is the average ranking method. This method uses metadata in the form of test results of a given set of algorithms on given set of datasets and calculates an average rank for each algorithm. The ranks are used to construct the average ranking. We investigate the problem of how the process of generating the average ranking is affected by incomplete metadata including fewer test results. This issue is relevant, because if we could show that incomplete metadata does not ?affect the final results much, we could explore it in future design. We could simply conduct fewer tests and save thus computation time. In this paper we describe an upgraded average ranking method that is capable of dealing with incomplete metadata. Our results show that the proposed method is relatively robust to omission in test results in the meta datasets.
                      <!-- /react-text --></span></span>
                   </div>

                   <ul class="citation-contexts" data-reactid="186">
                    <li class="citation-context-item" data-reactid="187"><span class="citation-context-text" data-reactid="188">
                      <!-- react-text: 189 -->We then evaluated the following genes, Actin, GAPDH, EF1a, 18S rRNA, and UBQ, in the roots and cotyledons of Chinese fir seedlings under five different abiotic stresses, namely, cold, high temperature (HT), abscisic acid (ABA), polyethylene glycol (PEG), and sodium chloride (NaCl). The data generated from qRT-PCR were then further analyzed using comprehensive and accurate tools for statistical analysis, such as NormFinder [28], geNorm [44], BestKeeper [45], and RankAggreg 
                      <!-- /react-text --><span class="citation-context-reference" data-reactid="190">[46]</span>
                      <!-- react-text: 191 -->, to determine the most appropriate one. 
                      <!-- /react-text --></span>
                     <div class="citation-enriched-context-actions clearfix" data-reactid="192"></div></li>
                   </ul>
                   <div style="margin-top:-2px;" data-reactid="193">
                    <h5 class="pub-type-and-title" data-reactid="194"><a class="js-publication-title-link ga-publication-item" itemprop="mainEntityOfPage" href="publication/305716232_Screening_and_Validation_of_Housekeeping_Genes_of_the_Root_and_Cotyledon_of_Cunninghamia_lanceolata_under_Abiotic_Stresses_by_Using_Quantitative_Real-Time_PCR" data-reactid="195"><span class="publication-title js-publication-title" itemprop="headline" data-reactid="196">Screening and Validation of Housekeeping Genes of the Root and Cotyledon of Cunninghamia lanceolata under Abiotic Stresses by Using Quantitative Real-Time PCR</span></a></h5>
                   </div>
                   <div class="abstract" data-reactid="197">
                    <span class="shorten" data-reactid="198"><a href="#" data-reactid="199">
                      <!-- react-text: 200 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 201 -->[Show abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a></span>
                    <span class="full" data-reactid="202"><a href="#" data-reactid="203">
                      <!-- react-text: 204 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 205 -->[Hide abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a>
                     <!-- react-text: 206 -->
                     <!-- /react-text --><span data-reactid="207"><strong data-reactid="208">ABSTRACT:</strong>
                      <!-- react-text: 209 --> 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 210 -->Cunninghamia lanceolata (Chinese fir) is a fast-growing and commercially important conifer of the Cupressaceae family. Due to the unavailability of complete genome sequences and relatively poor genetic background information of the Chinese fir, it is necessary to identify and analyze the expression levels of suitable housekeeping genes (HKGs) as internal reference for precise analysis. Based on the results of database analysis and transcriptome sequencing, we have chosen five candidate HKGs (Actin, GAPDH, EF1a, 18S rRNA, and UBQ) with conservative sequences in the Chinese fir and related species for quantitative analysis. The expression levels of these HKGs in roots and cotyledons under five different abiotic stresses in different time intervals were measured by qRT-PCR. The data were statistically analyzed using the following algorithms: NormFinder, BestKeeper, and geNorm. Finally, RankAggreg was applied to merge the sequences generated from three programs and rank these according to consensus sequences. The expression levels of these HKGs showed variable stabilities under different abiotic stresses. Among these, Actin was the most stable internal control in root, and GAPDH was the most stable housekeeping gene in cotyledon. We have also described an experimental procedure for selecting HKGs based on the de novo sequencing database of other non-model plants.
                      <!-- /react-text --></span></span>
                   </div>

                   <meta itemprop="name" content="Identification of Reference Genes for Quantitative Gene Expression Studies in a Non-Model Tree Pistachio (Pistacia vera L.)" data-reactid="249">

                   <ul class="citation-contexts" data-reactid="251">
                    <li class="citation-context-item" data-reactid="252"><span class="citation-context-text" data-reactid="253">
                      <!-- react-text: 254 -->These inconsistencies could be related to differences in the embedded algorithms in each software. Therefore, we applied RankAggreg, an R-based package to combine the ranking gene lists produced by the each software in order to determine the consensus rank 
                      <!-- /react-text --><span class="citation-context-reference" data-reactid="255">[28]</span>
                      <!-- react-text: 256 -->. Based on our rank aggregation results, EF1? and ACT have been demonstrated as the genes with highest expression stability in the leaf and salt subsets as well as in the whole dataset, whereas EF1? and ?-TUB are the best reference genes in the root, control, and drought subsets. 
                      <!-- /react-text --></span>
                     <div class="citation-enriched-context-actions clearfix" data-reactid="257"></div></li>
                   </ul>
                   <div style="margin-top:-2px;" data-reactid="258">
                    <h5 class="pub-type-and-title" data-reactid="259"><a class="js-publication-title-link ga-publication-item" itemprop="mainEntityOfPage" href="publication/304031073_Identification_of_Reference_Genes_for_Quantitative_Gene_Expression_Studies_in_a_Non-Model_Tree_Pistachio_Pistacia_vera_L" data-reactid="260"><span class="publication-title js-publication-title" itemprop="headline" data-reactid="261">Identification of Reference Genes for Quantitative Gene Expression Studies in a Non-Model Tree Pistachio (Pistacia vera L.)</span></a></h5>
                   </div>
                   <div class="abstract" data-reactid="262">
                    <span class="shorten" data-reactid="263"><a href="#" data-reactid="264">
                      <!-- react-text: 265 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 266 -->[Show abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a></span>
                    <span class="full" data-reactid="267"><a href="#" data-reactid="268">
                      <!-- react-text: 269 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 270 -->[Hide abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a>
                     <!-- react-text: 271 -->
                     <!-- /react-text --><span data-reactid="272"><strong data-reactid="273">ABSTRACT:</strong>
                      <!-- react-text: 274 --> 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 275 -->The tree species, Pistacia vera (P. vera) is an important commercial product that is salt-tolerant and long-lived, with a possible lifespan of over one thousand years. Gene expression analysis is an efficient method to explore the possible regulatory mechanisms underlying these characteristics. Therefore, having the most suitable set of reference genes is required for transcript level normalization under different conditions in P. vera. In the present study, we selected eight widely used reference genes, ACT, EF1?, ?-TUB, ?-TUB, GAPDH, CYP2, UBQ10, and 18S rRNA. Using qRT-PCR their expression was assessed in 54 different samples of three cultivars of P. vera. The samples were collected from different organs under various abiotic treatments (cold, drought, and salt) across three time points. Several statistical programs (geNorm, NormFinder, and BestKeeper) were applied to estimate the expression stability of candidate reference genes. Results obtained from the statistical analysis were then exposed to Rank aggregation package to generate a consensus gene rank. Based on our results, EF1? was found to be the superior reference gene in all samples under all abiotic treatments. In addition to EF1?, ACT and ?-TUB were the second best reference genes for gene expression analysis in leaf and root. We recommended ?-TUB as the second most stable gene for samples under the cold and drought treatments, while ACT holds the same position in samples analyzed under salt treatment. This report will benefit future research on the expression profiling of P. vera and other members of the Anacardiaceae family.
                      <!-- /react-text --></span></span>
                   </div>

                   <meta itemprop="name" content="Identification of reference genes for quantitative RT-PCR analysis of microRNAs and mRNAs in Castor bean (Ricinus communis L.) under drought stress" data-reactid="314">
                   <div class="indent-right" data-reactid="315"></div>
                   <ul class="citation-contexts" data-reactid="316">
                    <li class="citation-context-item" data-reactid="317"><span class="citation-context-text" data-reactid="318">
                      <!-- react-text: 319 -->The evaluation of candidate reference genes by different algorithms were combined for input to obtain a consensus stability order using an unweighted rank aggregation (Table 1 ). In this regard , Rankaggreg Rpackage calculated the distance among ordered lists using the Spearman foot rule function, and the consensus rank list was obtained by means of the Cross-Entropy Monte Carlo algorithm (
                      <!-- /react-text --><span class="citation-context-reference" data-reactid="320">Pihur et al., 2009</span>
                      <!-- react-text: 321 -->). This approach is recommended, since it provides a statistical support for consensus that strengthens the value of the reference gene in each situation. 
                      <!-- /react-text --></span>
                     <div class="citation-enriched-context-actions clearfix" data-reactid="322"></div></li>
                   </ul>
                   <div style="margin-top:-2px;" data-reactid="323">
                    <h5 class="pub-type-and-title" data-reactid="324"><a class="js-publication-title-link ga-publication-item" itemprop="mainEntityOfPage" href="publication/299131659_Identification_of_reference_genes_for_quantitative_RT-PCR_analysis_of_microRNAs_and_mRNAs_in_Castor_bean_Ricinus_communis_L_under_drought_stress" data-reactid="325"><span class="publication-title js-publication-title" itemprop="headline" data-reactid="326">Identification of reference genes for quantitative RT-PCR analysis of microRNAs and mRNAs in Castor bean (Ricinus communis L.) under drought stress</span></a></h5>
                   </div>
                   <div class="abstract" data-reactid="327">
                    <span class="shorten" data-reactid="328"><a href="#" data-reactid="329">
                      <!-- react-text: 330 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 331 -->[Show abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a></span>
                    <span class="full" data-reactid="332"><a href="#" data-reactid="333">
                      <!-- react-text: 334 -->
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 335 -->[Hide abstract] 
                      <!-- /react-text --></a>
                     <!-- react-text: 336 -->
                     <!-- /react-text --><span data-reactid="337"><strong data-reactid="338">ABSTRACT:</strong>
                      <!-- react-text: 339 --> 
                      <!-- /react-text -->
                      <!-- react-text: 340 -->Quantitative real-time PCR (RT-qPCR) is one of the most powerful and sensitive techniques to the study of gene expression. Several factors influence RT-qPCR performance though, including the stability of the reference genes used for data normalization. While the selection of appropriate reference genes is crucial for accurate and reliable gene expression analysis, no suitable reference genes have been previously identified in castor bean under drought stress. In this study, the expression stability of eleven mRNAs, thirteen microRNAs (miRNAs) and one small nuclear RNA were analyzed in roots and leaves across different levels of water deficit. Three different algorithms were employed to analyze the RT-qPCR data, and the resulting outputs were merged using a non-weighted unsupervised rank aggregation method. Our analysis indicated that the Elongation factor 1-beta (EF1B), Protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) and ADP-ribosylation factor (ADP) ranked as the best candidates across diverse samples submitted to different levels of drought conditions. EF1B and Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), and EF1B and SKP1/ASK-interacting protein 16 (SKIP16) were found as the most suitable reference genes for expression analysis in roots and leaves, respectively. In addition, miRNAs miR168, miR160 and miR397 were selected as optimal reference genes across all tissues and treatments. miR168 and miR156 were recommended as reference for roots, while miR168 and miR160 were recommended for leaves. Together, our results constitute the first attempt to identify and validate the most suitable reference genes for accurate normalization of gene expression in castor bean under drought stress.
                      <!-- /react-text --></span></span>
                   </div>

(function(){widgetLoader.createInitialWidget({"data":{"publicationFulltextFallbackViewer":null,"publicationUid":24026315,"abstract":"Researchers in the field of bioinformatics often face a challenge of combining several ordered lists in a proper and efficient manner. Rank aggregation techniques offer a general and flexible framework that allows one to objectively perform the necessary aggregation. With the rapid growth of high-throughput genomic and proteomic studies, the potential utility of rank aggregation in the context of meta-analysis becomes even more apparent. One of the major strengths of rank-based aggregation is the ability to combine lists coming from different sources and platforms, for example different microarray chips, which may or may not be directly comparable otherwise.\nThe RankAggreg package provides two methods for combining the ordered lists: the Cross-Entropy method and the Genetic Algorithm. Two examples of rank aggregation using the package are given in the manuscript: one in the context of clustering based on gene expression, and the other one in the context of meta-analysis of prostate cancer microarray experiments.\nThe two examples described in the manuscript clearly show the utility of the RankAggreg package in the current bioinformatics context where ordered lists are routinely produced as a result of modern high-throughput technologies.","publicationHeader":{"data":{"title":"RankAggreg, an R package for weighted rank aggregation","publicationUid":24026315,"publicationMeta":{"data":{"publicationType":"Article","publicationDate":"2009-03-01T00:00:00.000+0000","doi":"10.1186\/1471-2105-10-62","affiliation":"Department of Bioinformatics and Biostatistics, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY, USA. (function(){widgetLoader.createInitialWidget({"data":{"publicationUid":24026315,"abstract":"Researchers in the field of bioinformatics often face a challenge of combining several ordered lists in a proper and efficient manner. Rank aggregation techniques offer a general and flexible framework that allows one to objectively perform the necessary aggregation. With the rapid growth of high-throughput genomic and proteomic studies, the potential utility of rank aggregation in the context of meta-analysis becomes even more apparent. One of the major strengths of rank-based aggregation is the ability to combine lists coming from different sources and platforms, for example different microarray chips, which may or may not be directly comparable otherwise.\nThe RankAggreg package provides two methods for combining the ordered lists: the Cross-Entropy method and the Genetic Algorithm. Two examples of rank aggregation using the package are given in the manuscript: one in the context of clustering based on gene expression, and the other one in the context of meta-analysis of prostate cancer microarray experiments.\nThe two examples described in the manuscript clearly show the utility of the RankAggreg package in the current bioinformatics context where ordered lists are routinely produced as a result of modern high-throughput rank aggregation of cluster validation measures: A Monte Carlo cross-entropy approach","type":"Article","abstract":"Biologists often employ clustering techniques in the explorative phase of microarray data analysis to discover relevant biological groupings. Given the availability of numerous clustering algorithms in the machine-learning literature, an user might want to select one that performs the best for his\/her data set or application. While various validation measures have been proposed over the years...","longerAbstract":"Biologists often employ clustering techniques in the explorative phase of microarray data analysis to discover relevant biological groupings. Given the availability of numerous clustering algorithms in the machine-learning literature, an user might want to select one that performs the best for his\/her data set or application. While various validation measures have been proposed over the years to judge the quality of clusters produced by a given clustering algorithm including their biological relevance, unfortunately, a given clustering algorithm can perform poorly under one validation measure while outperforming many other algorithms under another validation measure. A manual synthesis of results from multiple validation measures is nearly impossible in practice, especially, when a large number of clustering algorithms are to be compared using several measures. An automated and objective way of reconciling the rankings is needed.\nUsing a Monte Carlo cross-entropy algorithm, we successfully combine the ranks of a set of clustering algorithms under consideration via a weighted aggregation that optimizes a distance criterion. The proposed weighted rank aggregation allows for a far more objective and automated assessment of clustering results than a simple visual inspection. We illustrate our procedure using one simulated as well as three real gene expression data sets from various platforms where we rank a total of eleven clustering algorithms using a combined examination of 10 different validation measures. The aggregate rankings were found for a given number of clusters k and also for an entire range of k.\nR code for all validation measures and rank aggregation is available from the authors upon request.\nSupplementary information are available at http:\/\/www.somnathdatta.org\/Supp\/RankCluster\/supp.htm.","url":"publication\/6346915_Weighted_rank_aggregation_of_cluster_validation_measures_A_Monte_Carlo_cross-entropy_approach","clickMilestone":"8CpaNErKywRC5qZ0BQXX_a_AluKUXd7Oh6y6pfa6E3xdtnafJZQrfMxB9IDOKk5V7agLK1rdaQziFbzGC4H-LKgjHSJMmqvbTMDDnsdm","publicationFiguresAuthorList":{"data":{"publicationUid":6346915,"totalCount":3,"initialDisplayCount":4,"defaultImages":{"defaultImageSmallURL":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4951093203564\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_s.jpg","defaultImageURL":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4671872220764\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_m.jpg","defaultImageURL2x":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/437738464651637\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_l.jpg"},"isLoggedIn":false,"isStatic":true},"templateName":"publicliterature\/PublicationFiguresAuthorList","templateHash":null,"id":"rgw34_59d973cf11fbf","widgetId":"rgw34_59d973cf11fbf","widgetUrl":"https:\/\/www.researchgate.net\/publicliterature.PublicationFiguresAuthorList.html?isStatic=1","stylesheets":[],"_isReact":true},"journal":{"abbrev":"BIOINFORMATICS","articleInfluenceScore":3.571000000000000174082970261224545538425445556640625,"catAuthor":null,"citedHalfLife":"6.9","eigenfactorScore":0.19672000000000000596855898038484156131744384765625,"fiveYearImpactFactor":8.135999999999999232613845379091799259185791015625,"id":null,"immediacyIndex":1.173999999999999932498440102790482342243194580078125,"impactFactor":4.9809999999999998721023075631819665431976318359375,"issn":"1367-4811","journalId":40517,"journalUrl":"http:\/\/bioinformatics.oxfordjournals.org\/","linkingIssn":null,"publisher":{"conditions":["Pre-print adaptive optimal ensemble classifier via bagging and rank aggregation with applications to high d...","type":"Article","abstract":"Generally speaking, different classifiers tend to work well for certain types of data and conversely, it is usually not known a priori which algorithm will be optimal in any given classification application. In addition, for most classification problems, selecting the best performing classification algorithm amongst a number of competing algorithms is a difficult task for various reasons. As...","longerAbstract":"Generally speaking, different classifiers tend to work well for certain types of data and conversely, it is usually not known a priori which algorithm will be optimal in any given classification application. In addition, for most classification problems, selecting the best performing classification algorithm amongst a number of competing algorithms is a difficult task for various reasons. As for example, the order of performance may depend on the performance measure employed for such a comparison. In this work, we present a novel adaptive ensemble classifier constructed by combining bagging and rank aggregation that is capable of adaptively changing its performance depending on the type of data that is being classified. The attractive feature of the proposed classifier is its multi-objective nature where the classification results can be simultaneously optimized with respect to several performance measures, for example, accuracy, sensitivity and specificity. We also show that our somewhat complex strategy has better predictive performance as judged on test samples than a more naive approach that attempts to directly identify the optimal classifier based on the training data performances of the individual classifiers.\nWe illustrate the proposed method with two simulated and two real-data examples. In all cases, the ensemble classifier performs at the level of the best individual classifier comprising the ensemble or better.\nFor complex high-dimensional datasets resulting from present day high-throughput experiments, it may be wise to consider a number of classification algorithms combined with dimension reduction techniques rather than a fixed standard algorithm set a priori.","url":"publication\/45694410_An_adaptive_optimal_ensemble_classifier_via_bagging_and_rank_aggregation_with_applications_to_high_dimensional_data","clickMilestone":"F9W8C5PXUxJ4NCWMSFVq1E3dRo4ncckPvdaE2BT6NAibWlbcdrGgVDhFc22PAzj1-UUC085saTdiRTXIOGXiES74eLZw_Y133YrB0Dzj","publicationFiguresAuthorList":{"data":{"publicationUid":45694410,"totalCount":3,"initialDisplayCount":4,"defaultImages":{"defaultImageSmallURL":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4951093203564\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_s.jpg","defaultImageURL":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4671872220764\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_m.jpg","defaultImageURL2x":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/437738464651637\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_l.jpg"},"isLoggedIn":false,"isStatic":true},"templateName":"publicliterature\/PublicationFiguresAuthorList","templateHash":null,"id":"rgw36_59d973cf11fbf","widgetId":"rgw36_59d973cf11fbf","widgetUrl":"https:\/\/www.researchgate.net\/publicliterature.PublicationFiguresAuthorList.html?isStatic=1","stylesheets":[],"_isReact":true},"journal":{"abbrev":"BMC Connected components (modules) from these networks are further inspected for their predictive ability for symptom severity, genotypes of two single\nnucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) known to be associated with symptom severity, and intensity of the ten most discriminative protein features. We use two\ndifferent network construction methods and choose the common genes identified in both for added validation. Our analysis identified eleven genes which may play\nimportant roles in certain aspects of CFS or related symptoms. In particular, the gene WASF3 (aka WAVE3) possibly regulates brain cytokines involved in the\nmechanism of fatigue through the p38 MAPK regulatory ","enforceShowingCompleteContext":true}},"additionalCssClasses":["includes-citation-list"],"abstract":"An initial reading list is prepared by researchers at the start of literature review for getting an overview of the research performed in a particular area. Prior studies have taken the approach of merely recommending seminal or popular papers to aid researchers in such a task. In this paper, we present an alternative technique called the AKR (Author-specified Keywords based Retrieval) technique for providing popular, recent, survey and a diverse set of papers as a part of the initial reading list. The AKR technique is based on a novel coverage value that has its calculation centered on author-specified keywords. We performed an offline evaluation experiment with four variants of the AKR technique along with three state-of-the-art approaches involving collaborative filtering and graph ranking algorithms. Findings show that the Hyperlink-Induced Topic Search (HITS) enhanced variant of the AKR technique performs better than other techniques, satisfying most requirements for a reading list. A user evaluation study was conducted with 132 researchers to gauge user interest on the proposed technique using 14 evaluation measures. Results show that (i) students group are more satisfied with the recommended papers than staff group, (ii) popularity measure is strongly correlated with the output quality measures and (iii) the measures familiarity, usefulness and \u2018agreeability on a good list\u2019 were found to be strong predictors for user satisfaction. The AKR technique provides scope for extension in future information retrieval (IR) and content-based recommender systems (RS) studies.","description":false,"hasMicroData":true,"isResearch":false,"isFulltext":false,"isSlurp":false,"isNoText":true,"hideAbstract":false,"hideTypeIcons":false,"publicationType":"Article","fileCategory":"Full-text","publicationDate":"May Recent studies have shown that polarized debates have a specific clustered structure in the endorsement net- work, which indicates that users direct their endorsements mostly to ideas they already agree with. Understanding these polarized discussions and exposing social media users to content that broadens their views is of paramount importance. The contribution of this demonstration is two-fold. (i) A tool to visualize retweet networks about controversial issues on Twitter. By using our visualization, users can understand how polarized discussions are shaped on Twitter, and explore the positions of the various actors. (ii) A solution to reduce polarization of such discussions. We do so by exposing users to information which presents a contrarian point of view. Users can visually inspect our recommendations and understand why and how these would play out in terms of the retweet network. Our demo (https:\/\/users.ics.aalto.fi\/kiran\/reducingControversy\/ homepage) provides one of the first steps in developing automated tools that help users explore, and possibly escape, their echo chambers. The ideas in the demo can also help content providers design tools to broaden their reach to people with different political and ideological backgrounds.","description":false,"hasMicroData":true,"isResearch":false,"isFulltext":false,"isSlurp":false,"isNoText":true,"hideAbstract":false,"hideTypeIcons":false,"publicationType":"Article","fileCategory":"Full-text","publicationDate":"Mar 2017","publicationFullDate":"2017-03-31","journal":"Plant Physiology and Biochemistry","publicationItemClickMilestone":"-HeCsv6MVlD2wo8OjUlJwXsesSQUtOn6XwVQN3nqfZw6D7i6jMY-VQ","publicationImage":"https:\/\/www.researchgate.net\/images\/template\/default_publication_preview_big.png"},"306474551":{"publicationUid":306474551,"publicationKey":"306474551_Effect_of_Incomplete_Meta-dataset_on_Average_Ranking_Method","authorsPartOne":[{"id":4930536,"url":"profile\/Salisu_Abdulrahman","fullname":"Salisu Mamman Abdulrahman","imageUrl":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4951093203564\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_s.jpg"},{"id":4208573,"url":"profile\/Pavel_Brazdil","fullname":"Pavel Brazdil","imageUrl":"https:\/\/i1.rgstatic.net\/ii\/profile.image\/AS%3A277595041091587%401443195223438_m\/Pavel_Brazdil.jpg"}],"authorsPartTwo":[],"surplusAuthors":null,"url":"publication\/306474551_Effect_of_Incomplete_Meta-dataset_on_Average_Ranking_Method","title":"Effect of Incomplete Meta-dataset on Average Ranking Method","additionalRightSideTopWidgets":{"type":"enriched","data":{"nextDetailPagePayload":null,"context":"mation exists, if in fact we have none. ","enforceShowingCompleteContext":true}},"additionalCssClasses":["includes-citation-list"],"abstract":"One of the simplest metalearning methods is the average ranking method. This method uses metadata in the form of test results of a given set of algorithms on given set of datasets and calculates an average rank for each algorithm. The ranks are used to construct the average ranking. We investigate the problem of how the process of generating the average ranking is affected by incomplete metadata including fewer test results. This issue is relevant, because if we could show that incomplete metadata does not ?affect the final results much, we could explore it in future design. We could simply conduct fewer tests and save thus computation time. In this paper we describe an upgraded average ranking method that is capable of dealing with incomplete metadata. Our results show that the proposed method is relatively robust to omission in test results in the meta ","enforceShowingCompleteContext":true}},"additionalCssClasses":["includes-citation-list"],"abstract":"Cunninghamia lanceolata (Chinese fir) is a fast-growing and commercially important conifer of the Cupressaceae family. Due to the unavailability of complete genome sequences and relatively poor genetic background information of the Chinese fir, it is necessary to identify and analyze the expression levels of suitable housekeeping genes (HKGs) as internal reference for precise analysis. Based on the results of database analysis and transcriptome sequencing, we have chosen five candidate HKGs (Actin, GAPDH, EF1a, 18S rRNA, and UBQ) with conservative sequences in the Chinese fir and related species for quantitative analysis. The expression levels of these HKGs in roots and cotyledons under five different abiotic stresses in different time intervals were measured by qRT-PCR. The data were statistically analyzed using the following algorithms: NormFinder, BestKeeper, and geNorm. Finally, RankAggreg was applied to merge the sequences generated from three programs and rank these according to consensus sequences. The expression levels of these HKGs showed variable stabilities under different abiotic stresses. Among these, Actin was the most stable internal control in root, and GAPDH was the most stable housekeeping gene in cotyledon. We have also described an experimental procedure for selecting HKGs based on the de novo sequencing database of other non-model plants.","description":false,"hasMicroData":true,"isResearch":false,"isFulltext":true,"isSlurp":false,"isNoText":false,"hideAbstract":false,"hideTypeIcons":false,"publicationType":"Article","fileCategory":"Full-text","publicationDate":"Jul ","enforceShowingCompleteContext":true}},"additionalCssClasses":["includes-citation-list"],"abstract":"The tree species, Pistacia vera (P. vera) is an important commercial product that is salt-tolerant and long-lived, with a possible lifespan of over one thousand years. Gene expression analysis is an efficient method to explore the possible regulatory mechanisms underlying these characteristics. Therefore, having the most suitable set of reference genes is required for transcript level normalization under different conditions in P. vera. In the present study, we selected eight widely used reference genes, ACT, EF1\u03b1, \u03b1-TUB, \u03b2-TUB, GAPDH, CYP2, UBQ10, and 18S rRNA. Using qRT-PCR their expression was assessed in 54 different samples of three cultivars of P. vera. The samples were collected from different organs under various abiotic treatments (cold, drought, and salt) across three time points. Several statistical programs (geNorm, NormFinder, and BestKeeper) were applied to estimate the expression stability of candidate reference genes. Results obtained from the statistical analysis were then exposed to Rank aggregation package to generate a consensus gene rank. Based on our results, EF1\u03b1 was found to be the superior reference gene in all samples under all abiotic treatments. In addition to EF1\u03b1, ACT and \u03b2-TUB were the second best reference genes for gene expression analysis in leaf and root. We recommended \u03b2-TUB as the second most stable gene for samples under the cold and drought treatments, while ACT holds the same position in samples analyzed under salt treatment. This report will benefit future research on the expression profiling of P. vera and other members of the Anacardiaceae family.","description":false,"hasMicroData":true,"isResearch":false,"isFulltext":true,"isSlurp":false,"isNoText":false,"hideAbstract":false,"hideTypeIcons":false,"publicationType":"Article","fileCategory":"Full-text","publicationDate":"Jun 2016","publicationFullDate":"2016-06-16","journal":null,"publicationItemClickMilestone":"A03Nh_9edputjgO406YXu5hzFsaVokMUAzAwQ4yF4QBHqlJxuHW-wA","publicationImage":"https:\/\/www.researchgate.net\/images\/template\/default_publication_preview_big.png"},"299131659":{"publicationUid":299131659,"publicationKey":"299131659_Identification_of_reference_genes_for_quantitative_RT-PCR_analysis_of_microRNAs_and_mRNAs_in_Castor_bean_Ricinus_communis_L_under_drought_stress","authorsPartOne":[{"id":6093148,"url":"profile\/Daniela_Cassol","fullname":"Daniela Cassol","imageUrl":"https:\/\/i1.rgstatic.net\/ii\/profile.image\/AS%3A294997791395840%401447344362682_m\/Daniela_Cassol.jpg"},{"id":2102706511,"url":"scientific-contributions\/2102706511_Fernanda_P_Cruz","fullname":"Fernanda P. ","enforceShowingCompleteContext":true}},"additionalCssClasses":["includes-citation-list"],"abstract":"Quantitative real-time PCR (RT-qPCR) is one of the most powerful and sensitive techniques to the study of gene expression. Several factors influence RT-qPCR performance though, including the stability of the reference genes used for data normalization. While the selection of appropriate reference genes is crucial for accurate and reliable gene expression analysis, no suitable reference genes have been previously identified in castor bean under drought stress. In this study, the expression stability of eleven mRNAs, thirteen microRNAs (miRNAs) and one small nuclear RNA were analyzed in roots and leaves across different levels of water deficit. Three different algorithms were employed to analyze the RT-qPCR data, and the resulting outputs were merged using a non-weighted unsupervised rank aggregation method. Our analysis indicated that the Elongation factor 1-beta (EF1B), Protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) and ADP-ribosylation factor (ADP) ranked as the best candidates across diverse samples submitted to different levels of drought conditions. EF1B and Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH), and EF1B and SKP1\/ASK-interacting protein 16 (SKIP16) were found as the most suitable reference genes for expression analysis in roots and leaves, respectively. In addition, miRNAs miR168, miR160 and miR397 were selected as optimal reference genes across all tissues and treatments. miR168 and miR156 were recommended as reference for roots, while miR168 and miR160 were recommended for leaves. Together, our results constitute the first attempt to identify and validate the most suitable reference genes for accurate normalization of gene expression in castor bean under drought : An R Package for Cluster Validation","additionalRightSideTopWidgets":null,"additionalCssClasses":null,"abstract":"The R package clValid contains functions for validating the results of a clustering analysis. There are three main types of cluster validation measures available, \u201cinternal\u201d, \u201cstability\u201d, and \u201cbiological\u201d. The user can choose from nine clustering algorithms in existing R packages, including hierarchical, K-means, self-organizing maps (SOM),\nand model based clustering. In addition, we provide a function to perform the self-organizing tree algorithm (SOTA) method of clustering. Any combination of validation measures and clustering methods can be requested in a single function call. This allows the user to simultaneously\nevaluate several clustering algorithms while varying the\nnumber of clusters, to help determine the most appropriate method and number of clusters for the dataset of interest. Additionally, the package can automatically make use of the biological information contained in the Gene Ontology (GO) database to calculate the biological validation measures, via the annotation packages available in Bioconductor. The function returns an object of S4 class clValid, which has\nsummary, plot, print, and additional methods which allow the user to display the optimal validation scores and extract clustering results.","description":false,"hasMicroData":false,"isResearch":false,"isFulltext":true,"isSlurp":false,"isNoText":false,"hideAbstract":false,"hideTypeIcons":false,"publicationType":"Article","fileCategory":"Full-text","publicationDate":"Mar 2008","publicationFullDate":"2008-03-01","journal":null,"publicationItemClickMilestone":"uQkxlG8BsZ3CNlr7vorXaVmiJXAgGF-qyqzqh041b9f4CiKNOiE9Tw","publicationImage":"https:\/\/www.researchgate.net\/images\/template\/default_publication_preview_big.png"},"222301696":{"publicationUid":222301696,"publicationKey":"222301696_Finding_common_genes_in_multiple_cancer_types_through_meta-analysis_of_microarray_experiments_A_rank_aggregation_approach","authorsPartOne":[{"id":38977022,"url":"scientific-contributions\/38977022_Vasyl_Pihur","fullname":"Vasyl Pihur","imageUrl":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4951093203564\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_s.jpg"},{"id":5571408,"url":"profile\/Somnath_Datta2","fullname":"Somnath Datta","imageUrl":"https:\/\/i1.rgstatic.net\/ii\/profile.image\/AS%3A278704442888216%401443459725681_m\/Somnath_Datta2.jpg"},{"id":1697685,"url":"profile\/Susmita_Datta","fullname":"Susmita Datta","imageUrl":"https:\/\/c5.rgstatic.net\/m\/4951093203564\/images\/template\/default\/profile\/profile_default_s.jpg"}],"authorsPartTwo":[],"surplusAuthors":null,"url":"publication\/222301696_Finding_common_genes_in_multiple_cancer_types_through_meta-analysis_of_microarray_experiments_A_rank_aggregation_approach","title":"Finding common genes in multiple cancer types through meta\u2013analysis of microarray experiments: A rank aggregation approach","additionalRightSideTopWidgets":null,"additionalCssClasses":null,"abstract":"Discovering genes involved in multiple types of cancers is of significant therapeutic importance. We show that collective evidence for such genes can be obtained via a form of meta-analysis that aggregates the results (rankings and p values) from various cancer-specific microarray experiments. This method is illustrated by a combined analysis of 20 microarray experiments. In the aggregated list of top-50 genes, 36 of them have been implicated in cancer (often multiple cancers) genesis in past studies, which also suggests that this list may contain some novel cancer genes that may deserve further scrutiny in the coenzyme A racemase as a tissue biomarker for prostate cancer","additionalRightSideTopWidgets":null,"additionalCssClasses":null,"abstract":"Molecular profiling of prostate cancer has led to the identification of candidate biomarkers and regulatory genes. Discoveries from these genome-scale approaches may have applicability in the analysis of diagnostic prostate specimens.\nTo determine the expression and clinical utility of alpha-methylacyl coenzyme A racemase (AMACR), a gene identified as being overexpressed in prostate cancer by global profiling strategies.\nFour gene expression data sets from independent DNA microarray analyses were examined to identify genes expressed in prostate cancer (n = 128 specimens). A lead candidate gene, AMACR, was validated at the transcript level by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) and at the protein level by immunoblot and immunohistochemical analysis. AMACR levels were examined using prostate cancer tissue microarrays in 342 samples representing different stages of prostate cancer progression. Protein expression was characterized as negative (score = 1), weak (2), moderate (3), or strong (4). Clinical utility of AMACR was evaluated using 94 prostate needle biopsy specimens.\nMessenger RNA transcript and protein levels of AMACR; sensitivity and specificity of AMACR as a tissue biomarker for prostate cancer in needle biopsy specimens.\nThree of 4 independent DNA microarray analyses (n = 128 specimens) revealed significant overexpression of AMACR in prostate cancer (P<.001). AMACR up-regulation in prostate cancer was confirmed by both RT-PCR and immunoblot analysis. Immunohistochemical analysis demonstrated an increased expression of AMACR in malignant prostate epithelia relative to benign epithelia. Tissue microarrays to assess AMACR expression in specimens consisting of benign prostate (n = 108 samples), atrophic prostate (n = 26), prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (n = 75), localized prostate cancer (n = 116), and metastatic prostate cancer (n = 17) demonstrated mean AMACR protein staining intensity of 1.31 (95% confidence interval, 1.23-1.40), 2.33 (95% CI, 2.13-2.52), 2.67 (95% CI, 2.52-2.81), 3.20 (95% CI, 3.10-3.28), and 2.50 (95% CI, 2.20-2.80), respectively (P<.001). Pairwise comparisons demonstrated significant differences in staining intensity between clinically localized prostate cancer compared with benign prostate tissue, with mean expression scores of 3.2 and 1.3, respectively (mean difference, 1.9; 95% CI, 1.7-2.1; P<.001). Using moderate or strong staining intensity as positive (score = 3 or 4), evaluation of AMACR protein expression in 94 prostate needle biopsy specimens demonstrated 97% sensitivity and 100% specificity for detecting prostate cancer.\nAMACR was shown to be overexpressed in prostate cancer using independent experimental methods and prostate cancer specimens.
